content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B}. The reason for this is that the payoff for both R and B against another R is the same (45$). However, the payoff for choosing B when the other player chooses R (35$) is slightly higher than the payoff for choosing R when the other player chooses B (0$ or 35$, respectively). Since the game has 75 rounds, I would expect a slight advantage from consistently choosing B over R in this scenario. This reasoning assumes that my opponent will not be able to adapt their strategy based on my choices, but it could change if they do.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

I will choose B again {B}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of B resulted in a payoff of 40$, and choosing B again maintains that payoff level, whereas switching to R could result in a lower payoff (35$ if my opponent chooses R, or 0$ if they choose B). Since we are playing multiple rounds, I would like to maximize my expected earnings as much as possible. Therefore, I will stick with my initial choice of B.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I will choose R this time {R}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of B resulted in a lower payoff (35$) compared to the higher payoff (45$) I could have earned if I had chosen R instead. By switching strategies, I can earn 10$ more in this round. However, it's important to consider that my opponent might also switch their strategy in response to my change, so we'll see how things play out over multiple rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

I will choose B this time {B}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of R resulted in a payoff of 0$, which is lower compared to the potential payoffs I could earn with other choices. Switching to B would allow me to earn 35$ in this round if my opponent chooses R, and it would also maintain the payoff level of 40$ if they choose B again. Since we are playing multiple rounds, I would like to maximize my expected earnings as much as possible by being adaptable and switching strategies when necessary.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I will choose B again {B}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of B resulted in a payoff of 35$, which is higher than the potential payoffs I could earn with other choices at this point (since my opponent chose R, I can only earn either 0$ or 35$). By sticking with my initial choice of B, I can maximize my expected earnings for this round while also maintaining the opportunity to potentially switch strategies in future rounds if necessary.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

I will choose B again {B}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of B resulted in a payoff of 40$, and choosing B again maintains that payoff level, whereas switching to R could result in a lower payoff (35$) or potentially no change if my opponent chooses the same strategy. Since we are playing multiple rounds, I would like to maximize my expected earnings as much as possible by being consistent with my initial choice of B and potentially adapting to new situations if necessary.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

I will choose R this time {R}. The reason for this is that my previous choice of B resulted in a lower payoff (35$) compared to the higher payoff (45$) I could have earned if I had chosen R instead. By switching strategies, I can potentially earn 10$ more in this round and also maintain the opportunity to earn 45$ if my opponent decides to switch back to B in future rounds. However, it's important to consider that my opponent might also be adapting their strategy, so we'll see how things play out over multiple rounds.

By sticking with my initial choice, I maintain the opportunity to adapt to new situations and maximize my expected earnings over the long term. However, it's important to keep an eye on my opponent's strategy as well and be prepared to adjust accordingly.
